abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fertilizer Support
            Project for Ethiopia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory,
            and borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the risk of a short-run emergency
            response compromising a long term World Bank supported
            reform effort should be assessed at design. Steps to bring
            the reform effort back on track if needed after the
            emergency should be identified. Health safety and
            environmental implications need particular attention in
            emergency projects such as Fertilizer Support Project (FSP)
            since their rushed implementation schedule often does not
            allow for mitigation plans to be put in place before
            implementation. A more sophisticated system of estimating
            demand, including an estimate of the optimum level of
            strategic fertilizer reserves between one season and the
            next would be important for ensuring efficiency of resource
            use in Ethiopia which is entirely dependent on centralized
            imports for its fertilizers.

14517529.owner: Agric., RD & Irrigt'n Prac 1 (AFTA1),IEG Public Sector (IEGPS)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fertilizer Support
            Project for Ethiopia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: Ethiopia has no explicit fertilizer
            subsidies and reforms are reducing credit guarantees and
            encouraging farmers to purchase fertilizer on a cash basis.
            During the project, field evidence and impact evaluation
            data from the project indicate that the large majority of
            farmers used cash to purchase fertilizer, and only in
            exceptional circumstances did local administrations support
            new credit guarantees. Experience under the project
            confirmed the ability and willingness of many small holders
            to pay cash for fertilizer. Under the project, a parastatal
            enterprise became the single importer of fertilizer in
            Ethiopia.' It remains the monopoly importer; through
            the procedures introduced under the project make this
            position contestable. Currently no evidence suggested that
            the single importer had measurable negative effects on
            fertilizer prices or distribution efficiency. On the other
            hand, economies of scale effects in the procurement and
            importation of fertilizer are small beyond certain amounts
            (50,000 tons) and therefore do not preclude multiple
            importers in the medium term.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fertilizer Support Project for
            Ethiopia concern to increase the likelihood that crop
            production in 2009-2010 will remain on or near the growth
            trend of recent years. To that end, the development
            objective is to contribute to the Government's efforts
            to ensure aggregate availability of supply of chemical
            fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production seasons adequate to
            meet smallholder farmers' priority demands. On April
            12, 2010 the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development
            notified the Bank that approximately 15 million USD remained
            in the designated account for the Fertilizer Support Project
            and requested that this amount be cancelled and recommitted
            to the Agricultural Growth Project (AGP) and subsequently on
            April 20, 2010 confirmed that all unused funds should be
            cancelled. In a letter dated June 7, 2010 the Government,
            recognizing that there was insufficient time to process the
            reallocation before the AGP financing proposal was due to be
            submitted for consideration by the Board of the World Bank
            Executive Directors, requested that the unused funds be
            instead made available to the Protection of Basic Services
            (PBS) Program Second Phase Project. The value of the balance
            remaining in the designated account of the Ethiopia
            Fertilizer Support Project as of April 12, 2010 when the
            cancellation request was first submitted to the bank is
            equivalent to SDR 10,382,471.90. The recommitment is sought
            by the Government in order to make full use of the remaining
            International Development Association (IDA) resources under
            a different ongoing operation. Since the Fertilizer Support
            Project has been fully implemented and is achieving its
            development objective, the remaining SDR 10,382,471.90
            cannot be used under this project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Fertilizer Support
            Project for Ethiopia is to increase the likelihood that crop
            production in 2009-2010 will remain on or near the growth
            trend of recent years.  The project has provided the
            Government with the needed foreign exchange resources to
            facilitate the import of fertilizer (urea and di-ammonium
            phosphate (DAP)) for the 2009 production seasons. Government
            reports, Bank supervision missions, and the draft impact
            evaluation study show that farmers have received fertilizers
            reasonably on time. Procurement, importation and
            distribution of fertilizer for the 2010 season is well under
            way, so availability of fertilizer for farmers is also
            ensured for the current season. The project development
            objective of contributing to the Government's efforts
            to ensure aggregate availability of supply of chemical
            fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production seasons adequate to
            meet smallholder farmers' priority demands is being achieved.

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Food Crisis Response Program
            Project - additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Food Crisis
            Response Program Project for Ethiopia is to contribute to
            the Government's efforts to maintain adequate coverage
            of the Ethiopia Productive Safety Net Program (PSNP) in
            2009, thereby ensuring that the project development
            objectives of the PSNP can be met. There is an immediate
            need to minimize the risk of a repeated food shortage. In
            the short-term, this can be achieved by ensuring adequacy of
            resources to: (i) continue to effectively support
            food-insecure households through the PSNP; and (ii) import
            critical agricultural inputs, primarily fertilizer. Unless
            the livelihoods of food-insecure households are protected
            and unless Ethiopian farmers have adequate supply of
            fertilizers, the food shortage Ethiopia is currently
            experiencing is almost certain to recur on a much larger
            magnitude, even with good rains. Over the longer term,
            complementary efforts to boost agricultural productivity and
            reduce vulnerability to shocks must be further strengthened.
